Expectation1: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation1: The ambulance driver is responding to a patient with symptoms of a major heart attack
Situation2: They plan to attend a family ceremony, making sure to arrive on time and wear appropriate attire.
Story: I glanced at the clock on the dashboard, my crisp kurta still smelling faintly of incense from the morning prayers. Today was my niece’s mundan, a sacred family ceremony I had promised never to miss. My mother’s words echoed in my mind: “You must be there, beta. It’s your duty.” But as I turned the ambulance key, the radio crackled—an emergency call. A man, mid-fifties, severe chest pain, barely conscious. My training kicked in: every second counts with a heart attack. I sped through the streets, siren wailing, my mind torn. My family expected me at the temple, to chant, to bless, to be present. My duty as a Hindu was clear. But the uniform on my back demanded something else: to save a life, to offer care, to put the patient first. My hands gripped the wheel tighter, heart pounding, as I wrestled with the impossible choice between my faith and my calling.
